title: Tidy Data Analysis
text:
Welcome






Warning



This book is still a work in progress.


This book is a guide on how to use a collection of packages in the R programming language called Tidyverse to analyse data.
I will use packages from the official Tidyeverse ecosystem, or packages that interact well with it, to load, manipulate, wrangle and visualise different freely available data sources.
At present, I assume that reader is familiar with the base R language. I will decide whether to cover an introduction to the R language later in time.
This work is for myself. It is the result of all the things that I learned about R, RStudio, and Tidyverse during the past years, and hopefully I will learn more while writing it. However, if you happen to land here, then feel free to have a look. And if you find that there is a problem, then please submit an Issue on the GitHub repository of the book.
This book was written with RStudio IDE using Quarto. The website is hosted via GitHub Pages. The complete source is available on GitHub.

title: 1  What is Tidyverse?
text:
1.2 Installing and Loading Tidyverse
Installing tidyverse follows the usual procedure for installing a R package.

install.packages("tidyverse")

Loading tidyverse in the current session produces the following message.

library(tidyverse)
#> ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──
#> ✔ ggplot2 3.4.1     ✔ purrr   1.0.1
#> ✔ tibble  3.1.8     ✔ dplyr   1.1.0
#> ✔ tidyr   1.3.0     ✔ stringr 1.5.0
#> ✔ readr   2.1.4     ✔ forcats 1.0.0
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
